sections.title: Introduction to Physics Concepts
sections.content: This section covers basic physics concepts, including displacement, velocity, acceleration, projectile motion, Newton's laws, forces, and momentum.

subsections.subtitle: Distance vs. Displacement
points: **Distance:** How far an object has traveled (scalar quantity – magnitude only). Example: 100 miles.
**Displacement:** Change in position, considering both magnitude and direction (vector quantity).
Displacement = Final Position (Pf) - Initial Position (Pi)
Displacement can be positive (east/north), negative (west/south), or zero.

key_terms.definition: A quantity that has only magnitude (e.g., distance, speed).
A quantity that has both magnitude and direction (e.g., displacement, velocity, acceleration, force).

examples: John walks 8 meters east and then 3 meters west. Total distance = 11 meters. Displacement = +8 - 3 = 5 meters (east).
A car travels 200 miles (distance) vs. 300 miles north (displacement).

subsections.subtitle: Speed vs. Velocity
points: **Speed:** How fast an object is moving (scalar quantity).  Always positive.
Formula:  d = vt (d = distance, v = speed, t = time)
**Velocity:** Speed with direction (vector quantity).  Can be positive or negative.
Velocity is associated with displacement while speed is associated with distance.

key_terms.definition: Total distance traveled divided by total time.

examples: A train moving at 45 m/s (speed). A train moving at 30 m/s west (velocity).
Object travels 12 m east (+12m displacement), then 20 m west (-20m displacement) in 4 seconds. Average speed = (12 + 20)/4 = 8 m/s.  Average velocity = (12-20)/4 = -2 m/s (west).

subsections.subtitle: Acceleration
points: **Acceleration:** How fast velocity is changing.  The rate of change of velocity.
Formula:  a = (Vf - Vi) / t (a = acceleration, Vf = final velocity, Vi = initial velocity, t = time)
Units: meters per second squared (m/s²).
If acceleration and velocity have the same signs, the object is speeding up.
If acceleration and velocity have opposite signs, the object is slowing down.
examples: A truck accelerates from 0 to 60 mph in 30 seconds (low acceleration). A sports car accelerates from 0 to 60 mph in 5 seconds (high acceleration).
Object with Vi = 12 m/s east, a = 4 m/s². Velocity increases by 4 m/s every second (16 m/s, 20 m/s, etc.).
Object with Vi = 24 m/s east, a = -6 m/s². Velocity decreases:  24, 18, 12, 6, 0, -6, -12, ... (slowing down then changing direction and speeding up).

subsections.subtitle: Gravitational Acceleration
points: **Gravitational Acceleration (g):** Acceleration due to gravity.  On Earth, g = -9.8 m/s² (in the y-direction).
Acts on the vertical (y) component of velocity (Vy), not the horizontal (x) component (Vx).
Negative sign indicates that gravity causes a decrease in velocity in the downward direction.
The moon has a lower g = -1.6 m/s².
examples: Ball dropped from rest (Vi = 0 m/s).  Vy decreases by 9.8 m/s every second (0, -9.8, -19.6 m/s, etc.).
Ball thrown upwards with Vi = 29.4 m/s.  Vy decreases until Vy = 0 (at max height), then becomes negative (-9.8 m/s, -19.6 m/s, etc.).

subsections.subtitle: Projectile Motion
points: **Projectile:** An object moving under the influence of gravity.
Friction is typically ignored.
Two-dimensional motion (x and y directions).
**Trajectory:** The path of the projectile.
Vx is constant during projectile motion (horizontal direction).
Vy changes due to gravitational acceleration.
examples: Ball rolling off a cliff with initial Vx = 5 m/s. Vy = 0 initially.  After 1 second: Vx = 5 m/s, Vy = -9.8 m/s.  After 2 seconds: Vx = 5 m/s, Vy = -19.6 m/s

Ball kicked at an angle with an initial velocity.  Vx = V * cos(θ), Vy = V * sin(θ). As the ball goes up and back down the Vy will decrease initially until Vy = 0 at its max height, and then become negative as it comes down.  Vx always remains constant.

subsections.subtitle: Newton's First Law of Motion
points: An object at rest stays at rest unless acted upon by a net force.
An object in motion stays in motion with the same velocity unless acted upon by a net force (inertia).
Friction opposes motion and can cause a moving object to slow down and stop.

key_terms.definition: A force acting through a rope.

examples: A box at rest needs a force to start moving (push or pull).
A box sliding across a surface stops due to friction.
Objects in space with almost no friction can travel forever (Earth orbiting the sun).

subsections.subtitle: Newton's Second Law of Motion
points: The net force acting on an object is equal to the mass of the object times its acceleration.
Formula: Fnet = ma (Fnet = net force, m = mass, a = acceleration).
examples: A 10 kg mass with a 80 N force applied (no friction). Acceleration = 8 m/s².  Velocity increases by 8 m/s every second.
